q: Mr Justice Holman, sitting in London, allowed challenges by six councils, including Sand-well, declaring Mr Michael Gove had unlawfully failed to consult them before the cuts. In five of the cases the failure was so unfair as to amount to an abuse of power, said the judge. He said: "However pressing the economic problems, there was no overriding public interest which precluded consultation or justifies the lack of any consultation." Mr Michael Gove 's decision-making

Michael Gove , the education secretary, said he was abolishing the the School Support Staff Negotiating Body because it does not fit well with the Michael Government's priorities for greater deregulation . But the Association of School and College Leaders has said the move is "a retrograde step" and could lead to staff who "play an immensely important role in providing high-quality education" being underpaid.

the Michael Government about the difficulties our schools face." He added: "This slash-and-burn attitude that the Michael Government has to local Michael Government must end." Leader of Sandwell Council Councillor Darren Cooper said: This is not about politics, it has gone beyond that. What we are talking about is the future of our children. I am absolutely delighted for Sandwell. He added that he belived Mr Michael Gove was no longer competent to make a decision on the future of these schools.
